section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, provide a set of five different-colored Connecting Cubes for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro, we learned that their families follow the harvests to pick tomatoes and other foods.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the harvests Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will pretend to pick tomatoes. You will each get five Connecting Cubes. We’ll pretend that these are your tomatoes. When I ask you to pick a number of tomatoes, count out that many tomatoes and bring them to me.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask I would like three tomatoes! Guide children to separate three Connecting Cubes from the group of five. Then count three tomatoes out loud while pointing to each cube.

Extend Ask children to count three tomatoes again, this time in a different order. I would like three tomatoes again. This time, I want the first tomato to be red. Guide children to count each tomato out loud, starting with a red tomato.
Repeat Continue to ask children to count three tomatoes, changing which color they count first each time. Repeat with different numbers.

Talk About Counting Use a set of cubes to count three tomatoes. Here are three tomatoes. One, two, three! Count each cube in a different order. Let’s start with this tomato instead. One, two, three. Are there the same number of tomatoes? How can you tell? Does it matter what order we count in?

Start the activity with three Connecting Cubes instead of five. Revisit one-to-one correspondence by visibly counting two cubes one by one, pointing to each as you count it. Then ask children for two cubes.

Ask for every tomato by color, and challenge children to bring them in the order in which you asked for them. Then ask how many tomatoes in all. For example, I would like one green tomato, one red tomato, and one blue tomato. How many tomatoes is that in all?
Use a set of your own cubes, and hold up the color of cube you are asking for as you say each color word. You may also hold up number cards to show the number of tomatoes you would like.
Consider having children draw the tomatoes rather than using Connecting Cubes. Ask children to count aloud each tomato they drew. Then, ask them to count the tomatoes in a different order.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Pattern Blocks for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro today, we talked about managing our emotions. We also counted cows in a field with Jovani and Alejandro!
You will make a cow using Pattern Blocks. Then, we will count the number of Pattern Blocks you used. I might get excited and make a mistake when I count! If I make a mistake, stop me.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Create Place the Pattern Blocks in the center of the table.

Count Ask one child to count the blocks he or she used to create the cow. Then, count each block yourself in a different order. Make a mistake as you count. Ask, Did I make a mistake? Oh no! How can you tell?

Extend Model taking a deep breath to calm yourself down. Then, count each block in the child’s cow again, this time coming to the correct number. Ask, Did I get the right number this time? How do you know?
Repeat Continue with each of the other children’s cows, first asking them to count and then counting yourself in a different order. Sometimes make a mistake, and sometimes count correctly.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When I got too excited and made a mistake, I also felt a little frustrated. But I took a breath to calm myself down before I counted again. What can you do to calm yourself when you make a mistake?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show the cow Pattern Block Card and have one child at a time make the cow.
Rather than recounting the Pattern Blocks yourself after you have made a mistake, encourage children to show you how to recount the Pattern Blocks in the new order.
Review new vocabulary before starting the activity, such as mistake, number, and cow. Encourage children to teach you how to recount the Pattern Blocks in both English and their home language.

Remind children to align the Pattern Blocks so they are touching. Show them how to hold one block in place while sliding the other until they touch. Slow, deliberate movements will result in a more precise shape.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need a set of 10 Two-Color Counters for each child and yourself, and as a “curtain.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro today, we counted the horses in different orders, and saw the number of horses in all stayed the same.
Let’s review the words order and in all.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the order and in all Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will pretend my counters are horses. I will count out a certain number of horses. Then, I will hide my horses “behind the curtain.” You will count out the same number of horses, and we will make sure our sets match!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Count out five horses behind the curtain using Two-Color Counters. Ask children to each count the same number of horses.
Match Lift the curtain. Count your set of five horses, and then each child’s set. Invite children to count with you. Make sure that each child’s set also contains five horses.
Extend Emphasize as you count each child’s set that everyone has five horses. Even though your horses are in a different order than mine, there are still five horses in all!
Repeat Continue the activity with different numbers of horses, placing each behind the curtain and asking children to match yours.
Talk About Counting Ask children whether the order in which they counted affected the total number of horses. Does it matter which horse you count first when counting all of your horses? Why not?
Start with sets of five Two-Color Counters rather than 10. You may also start the activity without the curtain, allowing children to see your set of horses as they count out their own.

Direct children to show their “horses” in specific colors. For example, I will count four red horses, but you count four yellow horses. Emphasize that both sets contain four horses, regardless of color.
Review the numbers one to 10 before you start the activity. You may also hold up numeral cards as you ask for each number of horses.
Invite children to act like each horse they count. Encourage them to stomp their horse feet and shake their manes as they count aloud each number in the set.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need 10 Connecting Cubes for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro, we saw two friends who love to spend time together. Today, we’re going to spend time with our friends while we work on making superheroes out of Connecting Cubes!
In this activity, you will each use the same number of Connecting Cubes to build a superhero. Be creative! Then, we will count the number of cubes in each superhero.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place all of the Connecting Cubes in the center of the table and ask children to build a superhero out of ten cubes. Encourage children to be creative, but to only use ten cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Describe your superhero. What makes your superhero special? How can your superhero be a good friend?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Have children count aloud the number of cubes in their superheroes.

Extend Emphasize that each child’s superhero has the same number of cubes, even though they are very different. Each of your superheroes are amazing and special! But each one was made with the same number of cubes.

Repeat Have children create a different superhero using the same 10 cubes. Have children count the cubes used in the new superhero. Emphasize that the number of cubes stays the same, no matter how children arrange them.

Discuss Sharing Talk about how children shared the cubes they used during the activity. We used so many cubes today! But each of you needed to build with 10 cubes. You shared the cubes with your friends. Why is it important that we share our cubes as a class?
Have children place a Two-Color Counter on each Connecting Cube as they count the number in their superhero. This will help prevent them from under- or over-counting any Connecting Cubes.
Challenge children to build a new superhero out of any number of cubes. Ask children, How did you like this activity? Was it harder or easier to share this time?
Review the term superhero before starting the activity. Suggest that children describe their superheroes using words from their home language and act out how superheros behave.
Have children pretend to be their superheroes once they are built. Encourage children to demonstrate the actions that their superheroes and superhero friends take to be good friends to each other.
